There continues to be no public information disseminated from the Taliban on COVID-19. The previous regime's online platform for the Ministry of Health remains online, however, information has not been updated since April 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210927222511/https://moph.gov.af/

While private testing is available for those who pay to travel, there appears to be very limited testing capabilities for the general public particularly in the weeks following the surrender of the Afghanistan government to the Taliban.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210927195450/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/512871/afghanistan-covid-19-related-measures-remain-largely-unchanged-nationwide-as-of-aug-13-update-18

There is no evidence any contact tracing is being conducted. There is very limited healthcare services remaining with nearly 1 in 4 hospitals treating Covid in Afghanistan have shut down. According to the WHO, âmedicines, medical supplies and fuel are running out in Afghanistan. Cold chains are compromised. Essential health care workers are not being paid.â    https://web.archive.org/web/20210927212317/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/08/25/afghanistan-coronavirus-pandemic-taliban/

Individuals must wear protective face coverings in public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920131630/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/525006/afghanistan-covid-19-related-measures-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-sept-16-update-19

COVID-19-related restrictions remain largely unchanged as of Aug. 13. Afghanistan authorities continue to require individuals to stay at least 2 meters (6.5 feet) away from each other and wear protective face coverings in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210808215045/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/afghanistan/coronavirus

According to UNICEF spokesperson, coronavirus immunizations fell 80 percent last week in the days following the Taliban victory, a spokesman for UNICEF, the U.N. childrenâs agency, said Wednesday. In the week beginning Aug. 15, just 30,500 people were vaccinated across 23 provinces â down from 134,600 people inoculated in all 34 provinces the week before.    As of 11 August 2021, a total of 1,809,517 vaccine doses have been administered. As of 16 September 2021, a total of 2,367,948 vaccine doses have been administered. However, priority for administration is unknown.  According to the WHO on September 22, about 2.2 million people, or about 6 percent of Afghanistanâs population, had been vaccinated against Covid-19. But in recent weeks, the organization said, vaccination rates have slowed markedly, and some 1.8 million vaccine doses in the country remain unused.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210927212317/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/08/25/afghanistan-coronavirus-pandemic-taliban/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210927214636/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/22/world/asia/afghanistan-covid-hospitals.html

Phased reopening across some states for prioritised grade levels, or all grades, primarily --   Maharashtra, from October 4, for all grades at 100% capacity: https://archive.vn/PRpCt  Tamil Nadu, from November 1, for all grades (higher grades are already in school): https://archive.vn/PZTp6    Other states still mulling reopening.  Kerala (expected 1 Nov)-- https://archive.vn/psnNG  Tamil Nadu -- https://archive.vn/zrM2D
Restrictions prevail across some states, implying that only priority workplaces have been allowed to open in these regions.   https://archive.vn/f2Fel

Gatherings and public events remain suspended in a number of states.   https://archive.vn/f2Fel    "New Delhi has eased a significant number of measures. Capacity limits will still likely be  encountered. Public fairs and exhibitions will be permitted provided they follow strict  hygiene protocols."  In West Bengal, restrictions are in place until 30 October. Both government and private  offices can reopen, with a cap of 50 percent imposed on staff strength.  â¢ In Tripura State, a curfew is in place for the majority of urban areas. Timings vary by  location.  â¢ In Tamil Nadu State, lockdown measures are extended through until at least 31 October,  with some easing.  â¢ The Madhya Pradesh government has eased lockdown restrictions. There will be separate  sets of unlocking guidelines for the places having the COVID-19 positivity rate above five  per cent and below 5 per cent. The weekend curfew from 22:00 on Saturdays to 06:00 on  Mondays will continue irrespective of unlocking.  â¢ A night curfew will run from 20:00 until 07:00 local time in Uttar Pradesh State. Easing will  take place based on infection rates.  â¢ Telangana State government has imposed a night-time. The curfew will be in place  between 22:00 and 06:00. All establishments will be required to close by 21:00, except  essential services.  â¢ The Jammu and Kashmir government has extended measures by district until further  notice. The general curfew is in place between 20:00 and 07:00 daily.  â¢ Curfews are in place across Himachal Pradesh State. Curfew time vary by district.  â¢ In Karnataka State, the night-time curfew will now run between 22:00 and 05:00 local time  until at least 11 October  https://archive.vn/Ik0kH
Depending on the state infection levels there are a number of states that are enforcing caps on the size of indoor gatherings.   https://archive.vn/f2Fel

Caps on public transport and closures in some states.   https://archive.vn/f2Fel    "Restrictions on travel and business vary for each state and in some cases each city.  â¢ Domestic flights can operate only 50 percent of their pre-COVID domestic flights, as  opposed to the 80 percent previously. Fares are also increasing in cost. Medical screening  and the use of face masks is still necessary"  https://archive.vn/Ik0kH

A number of states are still requiring individuals to stay at home, restrictions are imposed in the form of night curfews.   https://archive.vn/f2Fel  "Haryana has extended lockdown until 4 October. A statewide night curfew will be in force  from 23:00 to 05:00 seven days a week."

States are imposing a variety of restrictions on domestic travel, depending on the state of origin, for example Karnataka is requiring travellers from Kerala and Maharashtra to quarantine and obtain PCR tests upon arrival.     "Domestic flights can operate only 50 percent of their pre-COVID domestic flights, as  opposed to the 80 percent previously. Fares are also increasing in cost. "India has extended its general ban on international flight operations until 31 October. "RTPCR test must not be repeated in any individual who has tested positive once either by RAT or  RTPCR"  "Measures to improve access and availability of testing:  Rapid antigen tests (RATs) were recommended in India for COVID-19 testing in June 2020. However, the  use of these tests is currently limited to containment zones and health care settings. "
https://archive.vn/fXVwJ  Aarogya Setu app use encouraged but not enforced. Comprehensive contact tracing only conducted in containment zones.
Mask mandates still in place, required at all times outside the home (even in cars when traveling alone!)  https://archive.vn/UVTks

Supply issues previously reported seem to have eased, universal administration of vaccine to all those eligible (above 18 years of age)  https://archive.vn/QigWB    Covishield (a version of the OxfordâAstraZeneca vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India)   Covaxin (developed by Bharat Biotech)  Sputnik V (procured by Dr. Reddy's Labs from Russia; still being piloted in select cities and localities)    Note: while Moderna has been approved, there are no recorded instances of its deployment just yet.  Note: India just approved a DNA vaccine, acceptable for use for ages 12 and up https://archive.vn/l3Eka

Inbound international passenger flights are operational with protocols. Entry remains suspended for most individuals with travel history in the past 14 days to Angola, Botswana, Eswatini (Swaziland), Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia, Zimbabwe, and all South American countries and territories. Sri Lankan nationals, resident visa holders, foreign staff of UN or other international organizations, and foreigners invited by the Sri Lankan government may apply for exemption from the entry ban. These travelers must quarantine for 14 days at designated sites upon arrival. As part of the Sri Lanka Tourism bio-bubble program for travellers from countries on which no restrictions are placed, no restrictive quarantine is required however, a Negative COVID-19 PCR report (English) taken within 72 hours prior to embarkation is required by all travellers excluding children below 2 years.     [Unable to archive following links]  https://www.srilanka.travel/helloagain/  https://srilanka.travel/helloagain/documents/Health-protocol-Tourist-lat.pdf

Schools may reopen by obtaining permission from local authorities. Lockdown in Kathmandu Valley lifted, so schools are to run classes in-person from September 26th. Kathmandu Metropolitan City has decided to allow all the schools inside the metropolis to conduct in-person classes conditionally. Only schools that adhere to the 27-point minimum guidelines issued by KMC will be eligible to resume in-person teaching and learning activities.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210906223059/https://kathmandupost.com/valley/2021/09/02/valley-authorities-allow-conditional-reopening-of-schools  https://web.archive.org/web/20210927222002/https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/schools-to-run-classes-in-person

After nearly 18 months of very few tourists, Nepal has decided to reopen its borders to fully vaccinated travelers with no quarantine on arrival. Previously, visitors had to obtain special permission from Nepalese embassies and quarantine on arrival at their own expense for seven days. If tourists have received their final vaccination dose 14 days before arriving in Nepal, travelers can obtain a visa on arrival (which has stopped since March 2020) and wonât have to quarantine upon arrival.     However, partially vaccinated and unvaccinated travelers will have to obtain special visas from Nepalese embassies in their home countries. Plus, they will still have to undergo a 10-day quarantine in a government-approved hotel in Kathmandu. Theyâll also need a PCR test before they go out and explore after undergoing the mandatory quarantine.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210927222521/https://www.traveloffpath.com/nepal-reopens-to-fully-vaccinated-travelers-without-restrictions/

Last batch of AstraZeneca vaccines arrived from Japan.  By mid September 2021, 19.46% of the population (out of 30 million nepalese) have taken the first doses and 18.1% have been fully vaccinated.  As more than 5 months have passed, nepalese government has strongly encouraged all people to get vaccinated whenever possible.  According to the Health Ministry, additional 6,000,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccines (Vero Cell) arriving by October 15. According to the Ministry of National Health in Pakistan, from September 16, 2021, in high-risk areas, non-essential businesses must close by 8:00 PM with closures on Friday and Saturday. Some businesses, like cinemas, remain closed. Offices may only permit 50% attendance. Less stringent restrictions in place in low-risk areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917023912/https://twitter.com/nhsrcofficial/status/1438397442123354113

According to the U.S. Embassy in Pakistan, there are no curfews in place. While most places have reopened, there are COVID-19 mitigation protocols in place to limit hours of operation and number of patrons.  Government officials may implement lockdowns of streets and neighborhoods where COVID-19 outbreaks occur. Business hours are restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210925035010/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917023912/https://twitter.com/nhsrcofficial/status/1438397442123354113

Travellers are subject to a PCR test on arrival and if found to be positive, a paid for 10 day quarantine is enforced.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917115905/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/pakistan/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917115916/https://covid.gov.pk/intl_travellers/guidelines_for_travellers

All citizens aged 18+ can recieve Pfizer or Sinopharm or Sinovac, 1st jab is free.  All citizens aged 15-18 can receive Pfizer for free (1st jab only).  Ages 12-15 years  can receive Pfizer if paid for.  Immunocompromised citizens aged 12+ will be vaccinated with Pfizer for free.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917120724/https://ncoc.gov.pk/covid-vaccination-en.php

AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech, CanSino-Bio, Moderna, Sinopharm, Sinovac , Pakvak, and Sputnik V vaccines are available in Pakistan. Everyone 15 years old and up are eligible to be vaccinated.The cost is free to unvaccinated individuals.
